text: Cohen has finished his opening statement:" I am not a perfect man. I have done things I am not proud of, and I will live with the consequences of my actions for the rest of my life .. I may not be able to change the past, but I can do right by the American people here today"
author: NorahODonnell

text: Cohen: "I hope this committee and all members of Congress on both sides of the aisle will make it clear: That as a nation, we should not tolerate attempts to intimidate witnesses before Congress and attacks on family are out of bounds and not acceptable."
author: NorahODonnell

text: Cohen addresses the president: "I have fixed things, but I am no longer your 'fixer,' Mr. Trump."
author: NorahODonnell

text: Cohen: "Trump tasked me to handle the negative press surrounding his medical deferment ... He finished the conversation with the following comment: 'You think I’m stupid, I wasn’t going to Vietnam.' & I find it ironic, President Trump, that you are in Vietnam right now"
author: NorahODonnell

text:
Cohen: "It was my experience that Mr. Trump inflated his total assets when it served his purposes, such as trying to be listed among the wealthiest people in
Forbes, and deflated his assets to reduce his real estate taxes."
author: NorahODonnell

text:
Cohen: "He asked me to pay off an adult film star with whom he had an affair, and to lie to his wife about it, which I did. Lying to the First Lady is one of my
biggest regrets. She is a kind, good person. I respect her greatly – and she
did not deserve that."
author: NorahODonnell

text: Michael Cohen testifies that Roger Stone told then-candidate Trump in advance about the WikiLeaks release of DNC emails
author: NorahODonnell

text:
Cohen: "I knew early on in my work for Mr. Trump that he would direct me to lie to further his business interests. I am ashamed to say, that when it was for a real estate mogul in the private sector, I considered it trivial. As the
Pres., I consider it significant & dangerous"
author: NorahODonnell

text:
Michael Cohen: "Mr. Trump is an enigma. He is complicated, as am I. He has both good and bad, as do we all. But the bad far outweighs the good, and since taking
office, he has become the worst version of himself."
author: NorahODonnell

text: Michael Cohen: "Sitting here today, it seems unbelievable that I was so mesmerized by Donald Trump that I was willing to do things for him that I knew were absolutely wrong. For that reason, I have come here to apologize to my family, to the government, & to the American people"
author: NorahODonnell

text: Cohen: "during the campaign, at the same time I was actively negotiating in Russia for him, he would look me in the eye and tell me there’s no Russian business, and then go out and lie to the American people by saying the same thing. In his way, he was telling me to lie."
author: NorahODonnell

text: Michael Cohen: "I hope my appearance here today, my guilty plea, and my work with law enforcement agencies are steps along a path of redemption that will restore faith in me and help this country understand our president better."
author: NorahODonnell

text: Michael Cohen: "I am ashamed because I know what Mr. Trump is. He is a racist. He is a conman. And he is a cheat."
author: NorahODonnell

text: Michael Cohen: "I regret the day I said 'yes' to Mr. Trump. I regret all the help and support I gave him along the way."
author: NorahODonnell

text:
Cohen: "I recognize that some of you may doubt and attack me on my credibility. It is for this reason that I have incorporated into this opening statement
documents that are irrefutable, and demonstrate that the information you
will hear is accurate and truthful."
author: NorahODonnell

text: Ranking Member Jim Jordan says Cohen is a "Fraudster, cheat, convicted felon, and in two months a federal inmate."

text: .@nancycordes: "What we're watching for is do 2 Republicans out of the 51 Republicans in the Senate believe her story, and believe that this is disqualifying. Because if they do and they say they're going to vote no- and assuming all Democrats vote no - he doesn't have the votes"
author: NorahODonnell

text: Dr. Ford on her strongest memory of the assault: "Indelible in the hippocampus is the laughter. The uproarious laughter between the two. And their having fun at my expense."
author: NorahODonnell

text:
So this could not be a case of mistaken identity? -@SenFeinstein 

“Absolutely not.” – Dr. Ford
author: NorahODonnell

text: Dr. Ford testifies that she has suffered "claustrophobia and panic" as a result of the assault #Kavanaugh
author: NorahODonnell

text: Dr. Ford to Sen. Feinstein: "I haven’t held it in all these years, I did disclose it in the confines of therapy."
author: NorahODonnell

text: Prosecutor Rachel Mitchell in response to Dr. Ford's statement that she is terrified: "I just wanted to let you know, I’m very sorry. That’s not right."
author: NorahODonnell

text: Dr. Ford: "I have been accused of acting out of partisan political motives. Those who say that do not know me. I am a fiercely independent person and I am no one’s pawn."
author: NorahODonnell

text: Dr. Ford: "At the same time, my greatest fears have been realized – & the reality has been far worse than what I expected. ... I have been called the most vile and hateful names imaginable. These messages .. .have rocked me to my core"
author: NorahODonnell

text:
Dr. Ford: " In a letter on August 31, 2018, Senator Feinstein wrote that
she would not share the letter without my consent. I greatly appreciated this commitment. All sexual assault victims should be able to decide for themselves whether their private experience is made public."
author: NorahODonnell

text: Dr. Ford: "I thought it was my civic duty to relay the information I had about Mr. Kavanaugh’s conduct so that those considering his potential nomination would know about the assault."
author: NorahODonnell

text: Dr. Ford: "Brett’s assault on me drastically altered my life. For a very long time, I was too afraid and ashamed to tell anyone the details. I did not want to tell my parents that I, at age 15, was in a house without any parents present, drinking beer with boys."
author: NorahODonnell

text: Dr. Ford: "I believed he was going to rape me. I tried to yell for help. When I did, Brett put his hand over my mouth to stop me from screaming. This was what terrified me the most, and has had the most lasting impact on my life."
author: NorahODonnell

text: Dr. Ford: "I don’t have all the answers, and I don’t remember as much as I would like to. But the details about that night that bring me here today are ones I will never forget. They have been seared into my memory and have haunted me episodically as an adult."
author: NorahODonnell

text: Dr. Ford: "I am here today not because I want to be. I am terrified. I am here because I believe it is my civic duty to tell you what happened to me while Brett #Kavanaugh and I were in high school.”
author: NorahODonnell

text: Sen. Feinstein: "This is not a trial for Dr. Ford. This is a job interview for Brett Kavanaugh."
author: NorahODonnell

text: Sen. Feinstein: "What I find most inexcusable is this rush to judgment. The unwillingness to take these kinds of allegations at face value and look at them for what they are – a real question of character for someone who is asking for a lifetime appointment on the Supreme Court"
author: NorahODonnell

text: Senator Feinstein on the letter from Dr. Ford: "She asked me to hold it confidential, and I held it confidential up to a point where the witness was willing to come forward."
author: NorahODonnell

text: Grassley: "I can think of no one better equipped to question the witnesses than Rachel Mitchell." #Kavanaugh
author: NorahODonnell

text: Senator Grassley: "The FBI provided us with the allegations. Now it’s up to the Senate to assess their credibility." #Kavanaugh
author: NorahODonnell

text: “We live in a country where you’re presumed innocent and you have to corroborate accusations of felonies..It’s not that I don’t like Dr. Ford, it’s not that I don’t understand that women are being abused..But sometimes people are accused of things they didn’t do”-@LindseyGrahamSC
author: NorahODonnell

text: .@LindseyGrahamSC on the two men who have come forward claiming they may have been the man who assaulted Ford: “One’s crazy as a loon, I don’t believe the other one. I’m not going to play this game.”
author: NorahODonnell

text:
Why don’t you believe Dr. Ford? -@NorahODonnell

“I am a lawyer. I’m not going to assume that he’s guilty if you can’t tell me the year, the month, the place…what am I supposed to do? Abandon every concept we hold dear in our legal system to get an outcome?” -@LindseyGrahamSC
author: NorahODonnell

text: “If you’re expecting me to go ahead and ignore the fact that she cannot tell me when it happened, where it happened … I’m supposed to go ahead and ruin this guy’s life, when all the evidence suggests he’s not that way? I will not do that.” -@LindseyGrahamSC
author: NorahODonnell

text: .@LindseyGrahamSC tells @CBSThisMorning the accusation against Brett #Kavanaugh by Julie Swetnick is "garbage"

text: "Really all memory .. are fragments, pieces we remember and then we kind of turn it into a narrative afterwards. Sometimes that narrative can have inaccuracies … but usually the elements of it are the memories we use to structure that memory." -Dr. Ted Huey
author: NorahODonnell

text:
How reliable is the memory decades later? -@NorahODonnell

“What the research shows is that it matters kind of what you’re talking about. So the more peripheral memories might be mis-remembered as the decades go on, but usually the core is remembered pretty well." -Dr. Ted Huey
author: NorahODonnell

text: .@JanCBS on the #Kavanaugh hearing: "It’s going a lot about high school, and clubs, and what people said, and who they may or may not have dated - who knew what."
author: NorahODonnell

text: “One of the main takeaways from the Clarence Thomas/Anita Hill hearings is that everybody said 'that should never happen again.' So I think it’s been interesting to see some of the stuff – very similar to the situation that we’re in now.” -@JanCBS
author: NorahODonnell

text:
How unusual is it for a nominee to do an interview like this? -@NorahODonnell
“It’s never happened before that anyone can remember. But obviously, I think these are highly unusual times, and you could say some of these types of situations have never happened before too” -@JanCBS
author: NorahODonnell

text: Coming up at 8: Veteran Supreme Court reporter @JanCBS will share her analysis and reporting on the #Kavanaugh confirmation process - is he using the same playbook as Clarence Thomas?
author: NorahODonnell

text: "Even in the Anita Hill hearing, we had dozens of witnesses that came forward and were allowed to testify. This time, all of that’s being shut out. And as a former prosecutor, I think you have to be at least about to get the facts down" -@SenAmyKlobuchar
author: NorahODonnell

text: .@SenAmyKlobuchar on the #Kavanaugh interview: "And the second thing about that interview, is when he said that he actually downplayed his drinking. .. I mean those are things that really go to credibility given some of the stories circulating out there. "

text: .@MichaelOvitz on insulting Barbra Streisand in 1995: “I had a 15-year-old son at the time, and she wasn’t on the list of who they were talking about. That did not detract from her talent, she was just moving to a different demographic.”
author: NorahODonnell

text:
.@FBI Director Wray says China is our biggest counterintelligence priority – how is Microsoft dealing with that? -@NorahODonnell

“I would first say cybersecurity is almost job 1 these days. For every consumer, for every business, for every government on the planet.” -@BradSmi
author: NorahODonnell

text:
What are your concerns about AI? -@GayleKing

"We need to ensure that as we empower computers in effect to make decisions that have always been made by human beings, that these are decisions that are made ethically. .. It’s important that there be rules of the road" -@BradSmi
author: NorahODonnell

text:
She says there are gaps in her memory - are you okay with that? -@GayleKing

"You know the story is very transparent about what she does and doesn’t remember.. So yes I am absolutely 100% comfortable with the story." -@JaneMayerNYer
author: NorahODonnell

text:
Since your piece was published yesterday, have other women contacted you? -@NorahODonnell

"No, I haven’t heard from anybody else." -@JaneMayerNYer
author: NorahODonnell

text:
Where did the corroborating witness get the information from? -@JDickerson

“He remembers it from–he was in the same dorm .. and he remembers it clearly” -@JaneMayerNYer

But did he see it? -@JDickerson

“No. As I’ve said, he heard it from someone who was there.” -@JaneMayerNYer
author: NorahODonnell

text: "I know there’s pent-up demand for women to get their day, women who have been sexually harassed and assaulted, and I personally am very aggrieved for all of them. But are we going to put decades of pent-up demand for women to feel whole on one man’s shoulders?" -@KellyannePolls
author: NorahODonnell

text:
Should the new #Kavanaugh accuser be allowed to testify? -@NorahODonnell

"If she would like to, she can certainly contact the Chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee ..." -@KellyannePolls

text: .@KellyannePolls on #Kavanaugh allegations: "I just don’t think one man’s shoulders should bear decades of the #MeToo movement."

text:
Does the delay in reporting alone raise questions about Dr. Ford's allegations? -@jdickerson 

"It does not. Not to me." -@KellyannePolls

text: Prof. Jill Lepore: "Women’s historians have been writing incredible work for the last half-century, recovering the lives and voices of women ... If you don’t pay attention to women in the history of American politics, what you miss is a really crucial part of our political style"
author: NorahODonnell

text: I take it back to the Anita Hill example..where Pres. HW Bush did reopen the investigation based on her allegations, and look how those 302s were used. It was a brutal, brutal cross-examination of her in public. I’m not sure that’s a model we really want to follow. -@FranTownsend
author: NorahODonnell

text:
You're saying an FBI investigation might not help Dr Ford? -@GayleKing

“That’s exactly right..she through her lawyers has asked for this FBI investigation, and I think it makes her look political. This is very difficult..but I think she ought to tell her story” -@FranTownsend
author: NorahODonnell

text: “It’s going to come down to credibility. And so in the end the Judiciary Committee – and if the hearing is public, the American people – are going to be the judges of this. So I’m not sure what gets added to it by having the FBI do these interviews in advance.” -@FranTownsend
author: NorahODonnell

text:
What role should the FBI play in this? -@NorahODonnell

“The FBI - even if you were to reopen the background investigation -under no circumstances will they take a view on credibility. It’s actually part of the Justice Department regulations. That’s not their job” -@FranTownsend
author: NorahODonnell

text: Bryan Stevenson: "I never did meet a lawyer until I went to law school. And I want these young readers to imagine they can be a lawyer, that they can be a Dr..they can be anything they want to be. I had to believe things I’d never seen before to imagine I could be practicing law"

Would you put a crime survivor on the stand without first doing an investigation? - @NorahODonnell

"I believe that the FBI should be compelled to do its job in terms of completing their background investigation – and that’s not being done." -Sen. @KamalaHarris

text:
What is your process to determine who’s telling the truth here? - @GayleKing

text:
Would you be able to bring a case like this – 36 years old - to trial? -@NorahODonnell
@KamalaHarris: "Potentially. But..this is not about necessarily a criminal investigation, this is also about what we need to do around a background investigation into who #Kavanaugh really is"

text: Senator @KamalaHarris on Brett #Kavanaugh's accuser: "I think that we’re going to all be able to judge her credibility when she testifies before the US Senate. But I believe her."

text: .@KamalaHarris: I believe that the FBI should be compelled to do its job in terms of completing their background investigation–and that’s not being done..I’m not faulting the men and women of the FBI..but they’re not being given the authority to do it. That’s the concern I have.
author: NorahODonnell

text: .@KamalaHarris: "It’s not about proving a crime, it’s about his background. I have had many cases where there was enough evidence to believe something happened, but not necessarily prove it beyond reasonable doubt in a courtroom. But it doesn’t mean it didn’t happen." #Kavanaugh

text: Katz: “My client had a beer. She was not stumbling drunk. The men were stumbling drunk, and one only needs to look at the writings of Mark Judge –who was the other person present– to know that he wrote..that they were all drinking so heavily that they would black out repeatedly”

text: Ken Starr: "I will say – and I’ve said it many times – I regret all the pain that resulted, to so many including to the nation, of course I regret that. But no, I can’t in conscience say to Monica anything other than, ‘I’m sorry that the whole thing happened.’”

text:

text: .@SenJohnMcCain's casket is resting on the Lincoln Catafalque, which was built in 1865 to support Lincoln's casket when he lay in state in the Rotunda. The catafalque has held the caskets of presidents, Supreme Court justices and distinguished lawmakers who have lain in state

text:
Where did the politicization of the court start? 
@dkaplan007: “The Court in too many areas has intervened because it can, not because it should. So whether it was abortion in 1973 or Bush v Gore ...by overruling what the political branches had done, they made the stakes higher"
author: NorahODonnell

text:
What are the next big issues for the court?
@dkaplan007: “I think the key area … is going to be to deregulate what they call the federal administrative state .. I think taking apart power of the SEC, the EPA, OSHA – I think that’s the great grail for conservatives.”
author: NorahODonnell

text: .@dkaplan007: " Justice Brandeis said a century ago, the hardest thing we do is not doing. The court very infrequently chooses to stay out. And when it does stay out – like on partisan gerrymandering this past spring – those are the areas where they ought to get involved."
author: NorahODonnell

text:

text: #RealityWinner on @CBSThisMorning: "I love my country. I'm a patriot. I care about this country. And I want to make it as good as it can get."

text:
You've said this was a mistake. Was this mistake worth it?
#RealityWinner: "You know what I've learned in my time here? Is that you can disagree with someone til you're blue in the face. You can talk all you want. But what really matters is how you treat the person next to you."
author: NorahODonnell

text:
Do you believe you have the support of President Trump?
#RealityWinner: "I don't like to assume anything as to what's going on in his head. But the 'small potatoes' was a breath of fresh air."

text: #RealityWinner on @RealDonaldTrump's tweet about her last week:  "Our commander-in-chief, President Trump, has kind of come out and said, 'Wait a minute. This is really unfair. There's this double standard here.' And for that I can't thank him enough."
author: NorahODonnell

text:
Now that you know the consequences, do you regret leaking those documents?

text:
Are you hoping for a presidential pardon?
#RealityWinner: "You know, I'm not going to sit around and wait for blessings."

text:

text: .@JoshShapiroPA: “Child rape in 1970 is the same as child rape in 2018. It is unacceptable. And the idea that the Bishop would just simply say well this was a long time ago is demonstrably false, and it is absolutely the wrong response to this.”
author: NorahODonnell

text:
Q - Does it go up to the pope? 
@JoshShapiroPA: I know that it stretches to the Vatican. Look I’m a prosecutor, I deal in facts & evidence & apply the law. And I can tell you that there is facts, there is evidence that takes this cover-up and what occurred directly to the Vatican
author: NorahODonnell

text: .@JoshShapiroPA: I have received calls from more than a dozen AGs of both parties, from across the country ..Some of them have opened investigations, others have inquired as to how they should investigate, but unfortunately I think what we saw in PA.. is probably not unique to PA
author: NorahODonnell

text: .@JoshShapiroPA: "There are specific examples where the Vatican knew of this abuse, and they were involved in the cover-up."
author: NorahODonnell

text: .@JoshShapiroPA: There are specific ex. where when the abuse occurred, the priests would go, the bishops would go & lie to parishioners, lie to law enforcement, lie to the public, but then document all the abuse in secret archives that they would share oftentimes with the Vatican
author: NorahODonnell

text:
Q –Since [the report] was released, how many people have called your office?
@JoshShapiroPA: "Norah, we set up a special clergy abuse hotline, we’ve received as of late last night 733 calls to our clergy abuse hotline. In just the merely two weeks since this report came out."
author: NorahODonnell
